marketNews.title: Foreign Inflow Rp2 Trillion, IHSG Rebound +2.1%
marketNews.content: Indonesia's composite index (IHSG) rose by 2.11% to 7,196.02 on Tuesday (3/11) as foreign inflow reached 2.08 trillion rupiah. This marks the first inflow—both in the regular market and overall—after a series of outflows since 6 November 2024, which had driven the index down 4.12% over the past month. The amount is the largest foreign inflow since 19 September 2024, when a similar 2.08 trillion rupiah was recorded. Today's inflow consisted of 797 billion rupiah in the regular market and 1.3 trillion rupiah in the cash and negotiation market. The ten stocks with the largest net foreign inflow in the regular market today are listed. Key Takeaway: Although it is still early to conclude that foreign investors have returned to Indonesia, the end of the daily outflow trend is a fresh breeze for investors. Sectorally, interest-rate-sensitive sectors such as banking (IDXFINANCE +1.55%), property (IDXPROPERTY +1.12%) and technology (IDXTECHNO +3.18%) posted significant gains today.

marketNews.title: DOID Injects Capital AU$62 Million into Copper Mining Entity
marketNews.content:
Delta Dunia Makmur (DOID), through its subsidiary Bukit Makmur Mandiri Utama Pte. Ltd., announced that it will subscribe to newly issued shares of 29Metals Ltd. (ASX: 29M), a copper mining entity. 29Metals Ltd. will issue new shares worth AU$180 million, and Bukit Makmur Mandiri Utama Pte. Ltd. will exercise its pro-rata rights for approximately AU$62.1 million at AU$0.27 per share, a price 37% lower than the AU$0.37 level on the Australian exchange on Tuesday (3/11). After the transaction, Bukit Makmur Mandiri Utama Pte. Ltd. together with its affiliate BUMA Australia Pty. Ltd. is expected to hold 19.9% of 29Metals Ltd.

WIFI, through its subsidiary PT Integrasi Jaringan Ekosistem, announced a strategic partnership with Link Net (LINK) to develop information and communication technology (ICT) solutions across Indonesia. Under the agreement, LINK will be responsible for providing, managing and maintaining network infrastructure, while PT Integrasi Jaringan Ekosistem will handle internet service access, bandwidth provision, marketing, customer maintenance and brand ownership. WIFI CEO Yune Marketatmo said the collaboration is part of WIFI’s affordable internet initiative aiming to reach more than 40 million households nationwide.

MEDC reported that Medco Energi International, via its subsidiary PT Medco Power Indonesia, is ready to commercially operate three new renewable energy projects in January 2025: the Ijen geothermal power plant (PLTP Ijen) with 100 MW capacity, a solar power plant (PLTS) in Bali with 2 × 25 MWp capacity, and the Batam Electricity Project (ELB) with 39 MW capacity. Electricity from these projects will be purchased by PLN at US$0.0858 per kWh for PLTP Ijen, US$0.0592 per kWh for PLTS Bali West, US$0.0559 per kWh for PLTS Bali East, while the ELB tariff is undisclosed. MEDC is also processing the extension of contracts for two oil and gas blocks in East Java—Madura Offshore and Sampang—which are set to expire in 2027.

BFI Finance Indonesia announced an interim dividend for fiscal year 2024 of IDR 421.1 billion, equivalent to IDR 28 per share. The cum-date is 11 December 2024 on the regular and negotiation markets, with payment on 19 December 2024. Based on BFIN’s closing price on Tuesday (3/12), the implied dividend yield is approximately 3.1%.

ELSA reported that Elnusa plans to diversify its business in 2025 into chemical commodities for biodiesel through its subsidiary PT Elnusa Petrofin, which will trade sodium methylate oxide, a catalyst used in the production of fatty acid methyl ester for biodiesel. The move supports the government’s biodiesel mandate with a 40% crude palm oil (CPO) blend (B40).

NELY announced an interim dividend for fiscal year 2024 of IDR 35.3 billion, or IDR 15 per share. The cum-date is 10 December 2024 on the regular and negotiation markets, with payment on 27 December 2024. Based on NELY’s closing price on Tuesday (3/12), the implied dividend yield is about 3.3%.

SICO’s director, Prayoga Wisudharma, stated that the company targets a 12% year-on-year revenue growth and a 7% year-on-year EBITDA increase in 2025. To achieve this, SICO will raise compressor fleet utilization from 69% to 83%, improve operational efficiency with electric-motor-driven mini-gas compressors, and explore rental opportunities of mini-gas compressors to public fuel stations.

PSGO’s controlling shareholder, PT Jalinankasih Sesama, purchased 286.6 million PSGO shares at an average price of IDR 165 per share on 2 December 2024, amounting to a transaction value of IDR 47.3 billion. After the transaction, PT Jalinankasih Sesama’s ownership in PSGO increased from 43.501% to 45.021%.

CSIS plans a rights issue of approximately 3.9 billion new shares, which could result in up to 75% dilution. The issue price and ratio have not been disclosed; proceeds will be used for capital expenditure, working capital, and business growth or development. The rights issue will be accompanied by the issuance of warrants amounting to 392.1 million units, to be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders’ meeting on 9 January 2025.

The Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Bahlil Lahadalia, said the government will start implementing biodiesel with a 50% CPO blend (B50) in 2026, earlier than the previously targeted 2028, to reduce diesel imports. The Ministry of Agriculture estimates that B50 will require 20 million kiloliters of CPO per year, higher than B35 (13.4 million kiloliters) and B40 (16.08 million kiloliters). The government will begin applying B40 in January 2025.

Senior researcher Riyanto from the Institute for Economic and Social Research, University of Indonesia, forecasts that car sales in 2025 will decline by 12% year-on-year to 700,000-750,000 units if a 12% value-added tax (VAT) and vehicle tax surcharge are imposed in January 2025. Toyota Astra Motor’s Vice President Henry Tanoto warned that the tax increase would raise vehicle prices and reduce consumer purchasing power, further shrinking the domestic automotive market. The tax surcharge, collected by local governments on motor vehicle tax, vehicle transfer tax, and mineral tax, is considered an additional tax component. Fiscal Policy Agency analyst Rustam Effendi noted that the surcharge on motor vehicle tax and transfer tax does not need to be a concern as it will not increase taxpayer burden.

Customs and Excise Director General Askolani announced that the government will soon disclose an increase in the retail price (HJE) of tobacco products, though details were not provided. The Chairman of the Indonesian Cigarette Manufacturers Association, Henry Najoan, expressed hope that the government will not raise HJE or tobacco excise until 2027, as the industry is still recovering from recent excise hikes. He warned that higher HJE amid declining consumer purchasing power could boost illegal cigarette sales.

The Deputy Minister of Industry, Faisol Reza, said the government plans to raise the minimum domestic content (TKDN) requirement for smartphones sold in Indonesia. The exact new TKDN ratio and implementation date have not been set yet. The proposal comes as Apple Inc. is seeking to invest up to USD 100 million to obtain a 40% TKDN certificate for the iPhone 16, after previously offering USD 10 million, which the government rejected as insufficient.

Indonesia Stock Exchange (BEI) Director Irvan Susandy announced that from 9 December 2024, shares listed on the main board, new economy, and development boards will be tradable during the pre-opening session, whereas currently only LQ45 constituent stocks are eligible.

China’s central bank governor Pan Gongsheng reaffirmed plans to release accommodative monetary policy in 2025 to support economic growth, noting the importance of such policy amid potential US tariff increases on Chinese imports.

Japan’s central bank governor Kazuo Ueda signaled a possible rate hike on 19 December 2024, which would be the first three-time increase in a calendar year since 1989, citing persistent inflation, corporate investment plans, and rising wages.
